Text: Praise the LORD. How good it is to sing praises to our God; how pleasant and fitting to praise Him!
Context: The psalm opens with a call to praise God, highlighting the goodness and appropriateness of worship.

Text: The LORD builds up Jerusalem; He gathers the exiles of Israel.
Context: Depicts God’s restorative work in gathering His people and building up the holy city, symbolizing restoration and unity.

Text: He heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds.
Context: Emphasizes God‘s healing and caring nature, providing comfort for those in distress.

Text: He determines the number of the stars; He gives to all of them their names.
Context: Presents God’s omnipotence and omniscience in the vastness of creation, evoking a sense of awe in His abilities.

Text: Great is our Lord, and mighty in power; His understanding has no limit.
Context: Declaration of God‘s greatness and incomprehensible wisdom, underscoring His supremacy.

Text: The LORD sustains the humble but casts the wicked to the ground.
Context: Contrasts how God supports the humble and opposes the wicked, thus encouraging humility.

Text: Sing to the LORD with grateful praise; make music to our God on the harp.
Context: Encourages joyful praise and worship through music, reflecting a spirit of gratitude.

Text: He covers the sky with clouds; He supplies the earth with rain and makes grass grow on the hills.
Context: Highlights God’s provision and care for creation, fostering a sense of thankfulness for His sustenance.

Text: He provides food for the cattle and for the young ravens when they call.
Context: Continues the theme of God‘s provision, showing His attentiveness to all living creatures.

Text: His pleasure is not in the strength of the horse, nor His delight in the legs of the warrior.
Context: Reflects on what does not impress God, pointing towards divine values that differ from human admiration of power.

Text: The LORD delights in those who fear Him, who put their hope in His unfailing love.
Context: Defines what pleases God - reverence towards Him and trust in His steadfast love, showcasing a relational aspect of God with His people.

Text: Extol the LORD, O Jerusalem; praise your God, O Zion.
Context: Calls the community to corporate praise, emphasizing the role of collective worship in the life of God’s people.

Text: For He strengthens the bars of your gates and blesses your people within you.
Context: Assures of God‘s protection and blessings upon His people, referring metaphorically to the strength and security He provides.

Text: He makes peace at your borders and satisfies you with the finest wheat.
Context: Promises security and provision, evoking an image of a prosperous and peaceful community.

Text: He sends His command to the earth; His word runs swiftly.
Context: Describes the quickness and reach of God’s command, emphasizing the potency and speed of His word.

Text: He spreads the snow like wool and scatters the frost like ashes.
Context: Uses metaphorical language to portray God‘s control over nature, continuing the theme of divine interaction with the world.

Text: He hurls down His hail like pebbles. Who can withstand His icy blast?
Context: Depicts the power of God through the imagery of a storm, demonstrating His might and eliciting human limitation before it.

Text: He sends His word and melts them; He stirs up His breezes, and the waters flow.
Context: Shows the reversal of the previously described harsh weather, highlighting God’s command over the elements and His power to change circumstances.

Text: He has revealed His word to Jacob, His statutes and ordinances to Israel.
Context: Speaks of God‘s special revelation to His chosen people, honoring the unique relationship they have with Him.

Text: He has done this for no other nation; they do not know His ordinances. Praise the LORD.
Context: The passage concludes with an emphasis on Israel’s privileged position in knowing God‘s laws, setting them apart and ending with a note of praise.
